posts.post_content:
Wow, a lot of misinformation about Trinisphere in the comments. Let me try to help.  
  
Trinisphere literally has its very own layer, in the Comprehensive Rules for determining the cost of a spell. After every other cost modifier is processed, Trinisphere says, "if the cost for the spell at this point does not include at least three mana, increase an additional mana cost of ![1](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=1&type=symbol) or ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol) or ![3](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=3&type=symbol), the least amount necessary to ensure at least three mana have been spent."  
  
Alternative cost: Trinisphere introduces an additional cost on top of whatever alternative costs the spell requires. You can cast [Force of Will](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Force of Will) by paying ![3](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=3&type=symbol) and 1 life and exiling a blue card from your hand. You can cast [Deep Analysis](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Deep Analysis) from your graveyard (using flashback) by paying ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol)U} and 3 life. If you cast [Bloodbraid Elf](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bloodbraid Elf), you can cast the spell by paying ![3](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=3&type=symbol). (This also means you can't use cards like [Aluren](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Aluren) to get around paying ![3](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=3&type=symbol); wit... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
Wow, a lot of misinformation about Trinisphere in the comments. Let me try to help.

Trinisphere literally has its very own layer, in the Comprehensive Rules for determining the cost of a spell. After every other cost modifier is processed, Trinisphere says, "if the cost for the spell at this point does not include at least three mana, increase an additional mana cost of or or , the least amount necessary to ensure at least three mana have been spent."

Alternative cost: Trinisphere introduces an additional cost on top of whatever alternative costs the spell requires. You can cast Force of Will by paying and 1 life and exiling a blue card from your hand. You can cast Deep Analysis from your graveyard (using flashback) by paying U} and 3 life. If you cast Bloodbraid Elf, you can cast the spell by paying . (This also means you can't use cards like Aluren to get around paying ; wit... (see all)

posts.post_content:
I bought this version as a gift for a good friend for Christmas. He already had the original. This version is now sitting framed in his house, because the art and foil and flavor text alone made him cry a little when he saw it.  
  
I bought another version for myself, to use in my Artifact Deck. It wasn't the right deck for it, however, so now my copy is sitting framed on my desk, waiting for when I can get together four Force of Wills, a Stasis, and several other cards on my list for a new take on the Stax model.  
  
Happy Ruling, my friends.
posts.html:

I bought another version for myself, to use in my Artifact Deck. It wasn't the right deck for it, however, so now my copy is sitting framed on my desk, waiting for when I can get together four Force of Wills, a Stasis, and several other cards on my list for a new take on the Stax model.

Happy Ruling, my friends.

Posted By: Boakes2047 (5/7/2011 8:23:52 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: @Uhhsam No. You cast it without paying its mana cost at all. This just raises the mana cost it does have. If you were trying to play a spell that cost 0, however, that would be a different story, because that's just a manacost with a value of 0 (and would be raised to 3), as opposed to no manacost at all (in which case it would make no difference if the mana cost were 0, 3, or 3000000). Does that make sense?
posts.html:
@Uhhsam No. You cast it without paying its mana cost at all. This just raises the mana cost it does have. If you were trying to play a spell that cost 0, however, that would be a different story, because that's just a manacost with a value of 0 (and would be raised to 3), as opposed to no manacost at all (in which case it would make no difference if the mana cost were 0, 3, or 3000000). Does that make sense?

Posted By: Wraique (8/5/2010 8:36:28 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: I think I speak for most players, and I am sure many would debate that perhaps I am utterly and completely wrong. But this card is far too playable on turn 1. Infact it is so easy to play turn 1, that if I choose to play anything other the blue (via [Force of Will](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Force of Will) or [Daze](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Daze), my experience of Magic becomes pointless. A lock of this magnitude should not be coming from a single source alone. If you really want to debate this card, just test it yourself. Put together any deck that optimizes a turn 1 Trinisphere drop. Now run it against any other deck that doesn't use Force of Will or Daze. If the player with Trini draws an opening hand sphere, their chances of winning that game shoots up by 75% instantly. That shit is faster then Split Second! Now lets factor in getting hosed for mana. If your playing against trinisphere and you get stuck at 2 mana or less for whatever reason, the 75% jumps to almost 90% for the Trini player. The simple ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
For non-broken usage, I find that this actually works fairly well with Innistrad's werewolves.  
  
[Reckless Waif](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reckless Waif) on turn 1 followed by [Trinisphere](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Trinisphere) on turn 2 or 3 can make it incredibly difficult for your opponent to cast 2 spells a turn.  
Yes it makes subsequent Waifs more expensive, but you usually want to cast only one spell a turn anyway.
posts.html:
For non-broken usage, I find that this actually works fairly well with Innistrad's werewolves.

Reckless Waif on turn 1 followed by Trinisphere on turn 2 or 3 can make it incredibly difficult for your opponent to cast 2 spells a turn.
Yes it makes subsequent Waifs more expensive, but you usually want to cast only one spell a turn anyway.
